Ah-hah, but I am not going to define gravity. Quite the opposite.

The natural units where C = G = h = 1 make defining quantum and relativistic phenenema easier.

For all its worth, it is seldom used.

The primary reason is that G, the gravitational constant, cannot be defined beyond the 3rd digit. Recently papers have cited errors in experiments using different means of supercooling.

The critical problem with measuring G from celestials are:

-object density is estimated

-N-body problem in a galaxy that has dark matter at an unknown distance from where G is being measured.

-In the laboratory mass is so low that attraction is relatively small.

-In space only relative gravity changes can be measured accurately.

-mass of most objects is a function of energy (e.g. quark gluon interaction energy explains the overwhelming majority of mass in an object) getting rid of spurious energy for a true resting mass on a non-spinning object, difficult.

The argument of the other post centers around the assumption that gravity is well-defined, but comparatively speaking, gravity is not well-defined, it is approximated. This compares to measures of C defined precisely, and because h is a function of wavelength, the measure by which C defines a meter, planks constant is also well-defined.

G is the odd man out.

Meh. Good enough.

6.673E-11

That's 4 digits... Defined decently enough to work.
